case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Mir Mohd. Ali

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 145 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 16, 1959, of the Madras High Court in Case Reference No. 82 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 16. 1959, of the Madras High Court in Case Reference No. 82 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 24, 1964 by SIKRI, J.

anchor.surface_text: April 24, 1964. The judgment Of SUBBA RAo and SIKRI In, JJ. was delivered by SIKRI J.

facts.text: SHAH J. delivered a dissenting Opinion.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH J. delivered a dissenting Opinion.

facts.text: Appeal by the Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras, against the judgment of the High Court dated November 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: SIKRI, J.-This is an appeal by the Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras, against the judgment of the High Court, dated November 16, 1959,

facts.text: Certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A(2) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: on a certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A 2  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Respondent Mir Mohd. Ali is a bus owner and transport operator at Vellore, North Arcot District.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Mir Mohd. Ali, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a bus owner and transport operator at Vel- lore, North Arcot District.

facts.text: Assessee had a fleet of buses.

anchor.surface_text: He had a fleet of buses,

facts.text: During the year of account ending March 31, 1950 relevant to assessment year 1950-51, assessee replaced petrol engines in two buses MDJ 583 and MDJ 723 by new Diesel engines.

anchor.surface_text: and during the year of account ending with March 31, 1950  relevant to assessment year 1950-51  he replaced the petrol engines in two of his buses  MDJ 583 and MDJ 723  by new Diesel engines,

facts.text: Expenditure incurred: Rs. 18,544 in connection with replacement of engines.

anchor.surface_text: incurring an expenditure of Rs. 18,544/in this companynection.

facts.text: Before Income Tax Officer, assessee claimed normal depreciation under first paragraph of cl. (vi) of s.10(2), and also under second paragraph of cl. (vi) and cl. (via).

anchor.surface_text: Before the Income Tax Officer, apart from claiming numbermal depreciation under the first Paragraph of cl.  vi  of s. 10 2 , he also claimed depreciation under the second paragraph of cl.  vi  and cl.  via  of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer allowed only 25 per cent depreciation under the first paragraph of cl. (vi).

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer only allowed 25 per cent depreciation under the first paragraph of cl.  vi .

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, unsuccessful on this point.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed unsuccessfully to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on this point.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held assessee not entitled to extra depreciation under s.10(2)(vi) or s.10(2)(via).

anchor.surface_text: On further appeal, the Appellate Tribunal held that the assessee is number entitled to extra depreciation under s. 10 2   vi  or s. 10 2  via  because however important the engine might be for running of a motor,

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court: Whether extra depreciation admissible under s.10(2)(via) for diesel oil engine fitted to motor vehicle replacing existing engine.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, on the application of the assessee, referred the following question to the High Court Whether extra depreciation is admissible under the provisions of section 10 2  via  of the Income Tax Act,

facts.text: High Court amended the question to include s.10(2)(vi) and (via).

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court felt that there had been an accidental slip in framing the question, it amended the question as and the amended question reads Whether extra depreciation is admissible under the provisions of s. 10 2  vi  and section 10 2  via

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative, in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: of the Income Tax Act in respect of the diesel oil engines fitted to the motor vehicles in replacement of the existing engines. The High Court answered this question in the affirmative i.e., in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Commissioner filed appeal to Supreme Court on certificate under s.66A(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income Tax, on obtaining a certificate under s. 66A 2  of the Income Tax Act, has filed this appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court (Sikri J) held that extra depreciation is admissible.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that the High Court was companyrect in answering the question referred to it in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Shah J dissented, held not entitled to allowance under s.10(2)(vi) para 2.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.- I am unable to hold that the respondent is entitled to the allowance under s. 10 2  vi  paragraph 2, in respect of the diesel engines claimed by him.

facts.text: Bombay and Andhra Pradesh High Courts held against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The point at issue before us has been companysidered by three High Courts. The Bombay and Andhra Pradesh High Courts have held against the assessee

facts.text: Madras High Court held in favour of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: while in the judgment under appeal, the Madras High Court has held in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh HC in Srikantiah v. CIT followed Bombay and dissented from Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Andhra Pradesh, in the case of Srikantiah v. Commissioner of Income-Tax Andhra Pradesh 1 , followed the Bombay case and expressly dissented from the Madras case.

holdings.text: The High Court was correct in answering the question referred to it in the affirmative i.e. extra depreciation is admissible under s.10(2)(vi) and s.10(2)(via) in respect of diesel oil engines fitted to motor vehicles replacing existing engines.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that the High Court was correct in answering the question referred to it in the affirmative. The appeal, therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Diesel engine qualifies as 'machinery' under Privy Council definition; fixing in vehicle constitutes 'installation'; scheme of provisions does not restrict meaning of machinery; harmonious construction across clauses.

holdings.text: A diesel engine is clearly machinery according to the Privy Council definition in Corporation of Calcutta v. Chairman, Cossipore and Chitpore Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: What then is the test for determining whether a mechanical contrivance is machinery for the purposes of second para of cl. vi and cl. via ? The Privy Council in the case of Corporation of Calcutta v. Chairman, Cossipore and Chitpore Municipality 1  hazarded the following definition of machinery The word machinery, when used in ordinary language prima facie,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts ordinary language definition of machinery as mechanical contrivances generating power or directing forces; applies directly to diesel engine; supported by Income Tax Rules treating engines separately.

holdings.text: When an engine is fixed in a vehicle it is installed within the meaning of the expression in cls. vi and via.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that there is no force in this contention. As observed by the Bombay High Court in the case of Commissioner of Income- Tax v. Saraspur Mills Ltd. 1  the expression installed did not necessarily mean fixed in position but was also used in the sense of inducted or introduced

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Installed' means placed in position for service or use, per precedents from Bombay HC (Saraspur Mills) and Madras HC (Sri Ram Vilas); applies to fixing engine in vehicle.

holdings.text: Prima facie the same meaning must be given to the word 'machinery' in cls. (iv), (v), (vi) and (via) of s.10(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is then pertinent to point out that the word machinery occurs in cls. iv , v , vi and via of s. 10 2 . Prima facie the same meaning must be given to the word ,machinery in all these clauses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Word 'machinery' appears across related clauses for insurance, repairs, depreciation; requires consistent interpretation unless context dictates otherwise.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the scheme of the second para of cl. (vi) and cl. (via) that restricts the meaning of 'machinery' to self-contained units; plant definition in s.10(5) does not inform meaning of machinery.

anchor.surface_text: First, we do not think that there is anything in the scheme of the second para ,of cl. vi and cl. via that throws any light on the construction of the word machinery in these clauses. It is true that the machinery must be new and it must be installed and the rate of allowance is prescribed in the Act itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requirements of newness and installation do not redefine 'machinery'; s.10(5) plant definition resolves separate controversies without affecting machinery.

holdings.text: The respondent is not entitled to the allowance under s.10(2)(vi) paragraph 2 in respect of the diesel engines; question should be answered in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH, J.- I am unable to hold that the respondent is entitled to the allowance under s. 10 2  vi  paragraph 2, in respect of the diesel engines claimed by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Machinery/plant for initial allowance must be self-contained unit capable of independent use in the assessee's business; replacement engine lacks independent use in transport business.

holdings.text: Replacement of petrol engine by diesel engine in motor vehicle is not installation of machinery within s.10(2)(vi) para 2; must be self-contained unit for the business.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Committee in Corporation of Calcutta v. Cossipore and Chitpore Municipality 1  when it was called upon to consider whether a tank supported on columns, and which could be filled by pumping from a re- servoir belonging to the Corporation could be regarded as machinery within the meaning of the Bengal Municipal Act, 1884, observed at p. 445

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council definition requires machinery to be self-contained for the specific business; diesel engine replacement not independent in transport operation.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Chairman, Cossipore and Chitpore Municipality
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of machinery as mechanical contrivances which by themselves or in combination generate power or evoke, modify, apply or direct natural forces to effect specific result
precedents.cited_holding: The word machinery prima facie means some mechanical contrivances which, by themselves or in combination with one or more other mechanical contrivances, by the combined movement and inter-dependent operation of their respective parts generate power, or evoke, modify, apply or direct natural forces with the object in each case of effecting so definite and specific a result.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Cossipore and Chitpore Municipality
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of machinery in context of whether a tank is machinery
precedents.cited_holding: the word machinery when used in ordinary language, prima facie means some mechanical contrivances which, by themselves or in combination with one or more other mechanical contrivance, by the combined movement and inter-dependent operation of their respective parts generate power, or evoke, modify, apply or direct natural forces with the object in each case of effecting so definite and specific a result.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that the High Court was correct in answering the question referred to it in the affirmative. The appeal, therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that there is no force in this contention. As observed by the Bombay High Court in the case of Commissioner of Income- Tax v. Saraspur Mills Ltd. 1  the expression installed did not necessarily mean fixed in position but was also used in the sense of inducted or introduced
Accordingly, we hold that the High Court was correct in answering the question referred to it in the affirmative. The appeal, therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.
